title: 108_s1967
content: The Act may be cited as the "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" and authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account. The "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows account owners to transfer funds between accounts within the same institution, with certain limitations on the number of transfers permitted. The amendments made by the "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" include prohibiting institutions from offering demand deposit accounts if they are prohibited by law, with an effective date set for 2 years after enactment. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS. Repeal of Prohibition on Payment of Interest on Demand Deposits in various acts, including the Federal Reserve Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. Joint rulemaking required. The Secretary of the Treasury and Federal banking agencies must issue joint final regulations within 2 years to allow payment of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions. Regulations will define the scope of authorization and applicable account types. The regulations required by this subsection must include limitations, exceptions, and restrictions on authorization for payment of interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions. Definitions for "depository institution" and "transaction account" will be provided in the regulations, which must take effect within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The amendments made by subsection (a) of the Act will become effective either 2 years after enactment or when final regulations under subsection (b) take effect. The term "Federal banking agency" is defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. SEC. 4. PAYMENT OF INTEREST ON RESERVES AT FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, with payments made quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board may establish regulations regarding these payments and distributions. The Board may promulgate regulations regarding the payment of earnings, distribution of earnings to depository institutions, and responsibilities of institutions and agencies. The National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility oversees the distribution of earnings held in Federal reserve banks for depository institutions, including trust companies and corporations. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to include trust companies, corporations, and foreign bank branches. Section 19 of the Act is also amended to remove references to non-member banks. Subsection (b)(4) is modified by striking subparagraph (C) and redesignating subparagraphs (D) and (E) as (C) and (D) respectively. Subsection (c)(1)(A) is amended by replacing "subsection (b)(4)(C)" with "subsection (b)". SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than 8 percent (including zero). SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of certain escrow accounts. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of escrow accounts for real estate transactions, excluding them from being considered as interest payments under various laws. Exclusions for activities related to escrow accounts include absorbing expenses, forbearing from charging fees, and providing benefits to account holders or beneficiaries.
